I think a better question is why were attracted to soft things. Squishy things makes sense, in terms of our primal instincts. Back when we were roaming tribal people, fertility was important, and a woman with a squishier body was more likely to be able to have children. But why then do we ALL like squishy things and not just men? And why do we like soft fluffy things like fur? My guess is that usually fluffy things provide warmth, so our ancestors who were good at finding soft, warm things would better keep the tribe alive by being able to make blankets and clothing. But is that the real answer?
Room-temperature butter is pretty soft, too, but I wouldn't recommend running your fingers through it.

I have a feeling that the reason we can't figure it out yet, is because everyone who has tried so far, has been stuck in the same mindset; probably because of a preconception about what softness is.

I would recommend going through a large list of things that feel soft, and looking for examples that don't match out expectations based on material properties. Find those examples, and investigate them. And get help from someone who understands signals in the nervous system.

I have a hunch that softness is some kind of meta-property.

That video was talking about two different subjects to me.

In french you would use the word “mou/moelleux” to describe the opposite of hard aka: “squishy”

But you would use “ dou/douceur” when talking about the opposite of rough, as in the texture.

And those words are really not interchangeable! So I always found it strange how English lumps them both in one word.
